Lines.Text: pinch the two tabs locking the fan mount ( annotated in a blue square ) .
pull the mount up and out of the computer .

Steps.Text_raw: Pinch the two tabs locking the fan mount (annotated in a blue square). Pull the mount up and out of the computer.

Lines.Text: pull the orange connector out of the cd drive ( annotated in an orange square ) .
pull out the smaller connector ( annotated in a black square ) . tweezers make it easier but aren't required .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the orange connector out of the CD drive (annotated in an orange square). Pull out the smaller connector (annotated in a black square). Tweezers make it easier but aren't required.

Lines.Text: pull the cd drive lock ( annotated in blue ) straight up .
while holding the lock up , pull out the cd drive .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the CD drive lock (annotated in blue) straight up. While holding the lock up, pull out the CD drive.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two screws ( annotated with red circles ) holding the gpu heatsync in place .
swing it open then pull it straight up .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two screws (annotated with red circles) holding the GPU heatsync in place. Swing it open then pull it straight up.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two screws ( annotated with a red circle ) .
pull out the hinge for the gpu heatsync .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two screws (annotated with a red circle). Pull out the hinge for the GPU heatsync.

Lines.Text: pull out the yellow and black connector that is connected to the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out the yellow and black connector that is connected to the Motherboard.

Lines.Text: pull out the large white power connector that is connected to the motherboard .
use the plastic prying tool to pull it up .
alternate sides when prying until it comes loose .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out the large white power connector that is connected to the Motherboard. Use the plastic prying tool to pull it up. Alternate sides when prying until it comes loose.

Lines.Text: unscrew the three screws ( annotated in red ) .
slide out the ac adapter .
if all the cables are detached , it should slide right out . if not , detach the remaining cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the three screws (annotated in red). Slide out the AC adapter. If all the cables are detached, it should slide right out. If not, detach the remaining cables.

Lines.Text: remove the blue wire connected to the motherboard .
remove the orange wire connected to the motherboard .
remove the wide grey connector from the motherboard .
use the yellow handle to pull it up .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the blue wire connected to the Motherboard. Remove the orange wire connected to the Motherboard. Remove the wide grey connector from the Motherboard. Use the yellow handle to pull it up.

Lines.Text: remove the last wire connected to the motherboard .
remove the grey wire connected to the fan .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the last wire connected to the Motherboard. Remove the grey wire connected to the fan.

Lines.Text: unscrew the two screws holding the motherboard down ( annotated with the red circles ) .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the two screws holding the Motherboard down (annotated with the red circles).

Lines.Text: carefully lift the right side of the motherboard .
after lifting it above the fan , pull it to the right to remove the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Carefully lift the right side of the Motherboard. After lifting it above the fan, pull it to the right to remove the Motherboard.

Lines.Text: starting with the left side , insert the new motherboard .
once the ports are lined up , set down the right side of the motherboard .
then screw it back in and reassemble .

Steps.Text_raw: Starting with the left side, insert the new Motherboard. Once the ports are lined up, set down the right side of the Motherboard. Then screw it back in and reassemble.

Subject: Motherboard

Title: Dell Inspiron 531 Graphics Card Replacement

Lines.Text: place the desktop on its side . make sure to place the computer on a soft but firm surface .
locate and remove the two screws that secure the side panel to the desktop :
two 1 /4 phillips/slotted combination screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the desktop on its side. Make sure to place the computer on a soft but firm surface. Locate and remove the two screws that secure the side panel to the desktop: Two 1/4" Phillips/slotted combination screws.

Lines.Text: slide the side panel towards the back of the desktop in order to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Slide the side panel towards the back of the desktop in order to remove it.

Lines.Text: the graphics card is attached to the back of the desktop .
the graphics card is located below the three fans .

Steps.Text_raw: The graphics card is attached to the back of the desktop. The graphics card is located below the three fans.

Lines.Text: remove the screw that secures the support bracket :
one 1 /4 phillips screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the screw that secures the support bracket: One 1/4" Phillips screw

Lines.Text: remove the support bracket by lifting up and out .
there are tabs that hold the bracket in place , therefor lifting up is an important detail .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the support bracket  by lifting up and out. There are tabs that hold the bracket in place, therefor lifting up is an important detail.

Lines.Text: locate the push tab that locks the graphics card into place .
push the tab away from the graphics card and towards the fan .
hold the tab in this position through step 7.

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the push tab that locks the graphics card into place. Push the tab away from the graphics card and towards the fan. Hold the tab in this position through step 7.

Lines.Text: keep the tab pushed away from the graphics card ( see step 6 ) .
gently lift the graphics card up and out of the desktop .

Steps.Text_raw: Keep the tab pushed away from the graphics card (see Step 6). Gently lift the graphics card up and out of the desktop.

Lines.Text: remove the two screws holding the vga ribbon cable to the bracket :
two m3 hex standoff screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws holding the VGA ribbon cable to the bracket: Two M3 hex standoff screws.

Lines.Text: gently unplug the ribbon cable from the header pins .
remove the other end of the ribbon cable from the bracket .

Steps.Text_raw: Gently unplug the ribbon cable from the header pins. Remove the other end of the ribbon cable from the bracket.

Lines.Text: remove the two screws holding the dvi adaptor to the bracket :
two m3 hex standoff screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws holding the DVI adaptor to the bracket: Two M3 hex standoff screws.

Lines.Text: remove the bracket from the graphics card .
the job is done ! you can now put the better graphics card in and bask in the joy of an enhanced visual experience .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the bracket from the graphics card. The job is done! You can now put the better graphics card in and bask in the joy of an enhanced visual experience.

Subject: Graphics Card

Title: HP Touchsmart IQ506 CMOS Battery Replacement

Lines.Text: unplug the system from the power brick .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the system from the power brick.

Lines.Text: i did not get the original keyboard with my system and the receiver mine came with was broken . since the hp oem keyboard is end of life , i chose to install a usb hub because i cannot find a modern keyboard with a large receiver .

to remove the back cover from the system , the keyboard receiver must be removed . to do this , pull the ab on the case down . once you do this , it should come out of the internal usb port and free the back cover for removal .

Steps.Text_raw: I did not get the original keyboard with my system and the receiver mine came with was broken. Since the HP OEM keyboard is end of life, I chose to install a USB hub because I cannot find a modern keyboard with a large receiver. To remove the back cover from the system, the keyboard receiver must be removed. To do this, pull the ab on the case down. Once you do this, it should come out of the internal USB port and free the back cover for removal.

Lines.Text: unscrew the ram door from the system . once you do this , unclip it from the bottom and pull forward .

Steps.Text_raw: Unscrew the RAM door from the system. Once you do this, unclip it from the bottom and pull forward.

Lines.Text: the top hinge screws can be difficult to get to . if you are using the classic ifixit screwdriver handle , the best workaround to this problem is to put the extension on and twist this part to remove the top screws . this is not required for the bottom screws .

Steps.Text_raw: The top hinge screws can be difficult to get to. If you are using the classic iFixit screwdriver handle, the best workaround to this problem is to put the extension on and twist this part to remove the top screws. This is not required for the bottom screws.

Lines.Text: some people may find it easier to remove the top screws from the stand first . these screws can be difficult to remove .
remove the stand from the system . use a phillips 1 screwdriver to loosen the 4 screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Some people may find it easier to remove the top screws from the stand first. These screws can be difficult to remove. Remove the stand from the system. Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to loosen the 4 screws.

Lines.Text: remove the 3 screws in the i/o bay of the system .
remove the 2 screws from under the ram panel . '''note : ''' on my system , i am missing one screw .
remove the 2 screws from under the odd cover . '''note : ''' if you are having trouble with this cover , use a spudger or plastic pry tool to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 3 screws in the I/O bay of the system. Remove the 2 screws from under the RAM panel. '''Note:''' On my system, I am missing one screw. Remove the 2 screws from under the ODD cover. '''Note:''' If you are having trouble with this cover, use a spudger or plastic pry tool to remove it.

Lines.Text: remove the 2 screws by the feet on the system chassis .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 2 screws by the feet on the system chassis.

Lines.Text: if you are having a hard time removing the back of the system , a spudger can make it easier to unsnap the rear plastic cover .
remove the back from the system . to do this the quickest with the least amount of pain , remove the bottom and work your way up .

Steps.Text_raw: If you are having a hard time removing the back of the system, a spudger can make it easier to unsnap the rear plastic cover. Remove the back from the system. To do this the quickest with the least amount of pain, remove the bottom and work your way up.

Lines.Text: the metal emi shield over the power jack has to be removed to pull the motherboard shield off . this must be replaced when reassembling the system .
remove the '''7 ''' screws to reveal the motherboard and other major components . use a '''phillips 1 ''' screwdriver to do this .

Steps.Text_raw: The metal EMI shield over the power jack has to be removed to pull the motherboard shield off. This must be replaced when reassembling the system. Remove the '''7''' screws to reveal the motherboard and other major components. Use a '''Phillips #1''' screwdriver to do this.

Lines.Text: remove the '''6 ''' remaining screws from the motherboard shield . use the same phillips 1 screwdriver as you used the first time .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the '''6''' remaining screws from the motherboard shield. Use the same Phillips #1 screwdriver as you used the first time.

Lines.Text: if you want to track when you replaced the battery , put a mark on the battery with the month and year so you know when it was replaced . if you cannot write on the battery , putting a hidden note under the memory panel is also an option .
push the tab on the battery in and then remove it . put the new battery in the reverse way of removal .

Steps.Text_raw: If you want to track when you replaced the battery, put a mark on the battery with the month and year so you know when it was replaced. If you cannot write on the battery, putting a hidden note under the memory panel is also an option. Push the tab on the battery in and then remove it. Put the new battery in the reverse way of removal.

Subject: CMOS Battery

Title: HP 310-1037 Hard Drive Replacement

Lines.Text: hp310-1037 touchsmart pc with a dead hard drive . the hard drive is located behind the stand cover .
lay the pc flat on the front to gain access to the stand cover
remove the single screw that holds the stand cover to the chassis with a flat tip screwdriver

Steps.Text_raw: HP310-1037 Touchsmart PC with a dead hard drive. The hard drive is located behind the stand cover. Lay the PC flat on the front to gain access to the stand cover Remove the single screw that holds the stand cover to the chassis with a flat tip screwdriver

Lines.Text: remove the stand cover
the hard drive caddy is held in place with 1 phillips screw
use a 0 phillips screwdriver to remove that screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the stand cover The hard drive caddy is held in place with 1 Phillips screw Use a #0 Phillips screwdriver to remove that screw

Lines.Text: lift the handle on the hard drive caddy
and pull it to the backside . this will remove the hard drive caddy from the computer .
to remove the hard drive from the caddy , turn it over . there are four phillips scres that hold the hard drive in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the handle on the hard drive caddy and pull it to the backside. This will remove the hard drive caddy from the computer. To remove the hard drive from the caddy, turn it over. There are four Phillips scres that hold the hard drive in place.

Lines.Text: once the four screws are removed , slide the hard drive out of the caddy .
here is the failed drive . it is a hitachi hds721010 cla332. failure with this drive is all to common .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the four screws are removed, slide the hard drive out of the caddy. Here is the failed drive. It is a Hitachi HDS721010CLA332. Failure with this drive is all to common.

Subject: Hard Drive

Title: Surface Studio M.2 SSD Replacement

Lines.Text: lay the surface face down on a padded surface
be careful not to scratch the screen when laying it face down
remove the four rubber feet at each corner concealing the torx screws
remove the four torx screws under the rubber feet .
two screws on the upper corners are longer than two screws on the lower corners .
attach suction cups to the bottom cover and then pull on the suction cups to free the bottom cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Lay the Surface face down on a padded surface Be careful not to scratch the screen when laying it face down Remove the four rubber feet at each corner concealing the Torx screws Remove the four Torx screws under the rubber feet. Two screws on the upper corners are longer than two screws on the lower corners. Attach suction cups to the bottom cover and then pull on the suction cups to free the bottom cover.

Lines.Text: remove five torx screws holding the two fans to the midframe
remove the two fans
the fan connectors are behind the midframe and not yet accessible . let the fans hang loosely until you can access the connectors .
four large torx screws and four small torx screws hold the midframe to the upper frame .
remove four large torx screws holding the midframe
remove four small torx screws holding the midframe

Steps.Text_raw: Remove five torx screws holding the two fans to the midframe Remove the two fans The fan connectors are behind the midframe and not yet accessible. Let the fans hang loosely until you can access the connectors. Four large torx screws and four small torx screws hold the midframe to the upper frame. Remove four large torx screws holding the midframe Remove four small torx screws holding the midframe

Lines.Text: slowly remove the midframe
be careful , the speaker on the midframe is still attached to the motherboard
detach the connectors for the two fans and the speaker

Steps.Text_raw: Slowly remove the midframe Be careful, the speaker on the midframe is still attached to the motherboard Detach the connectors for the two fans and the speaker

Lines.Text: with the midframe removed , the m . 2 ssd is now accessible
remove a torx screw holding the m . 2 holding the ssd to the motherboard
pull the ssd straight back
do not pull the ssd upward or risk damaging the m . 2 socket
the m . 2 socket is compatible with most sata iii , pcie achi , and pcie nvme in the m . 2 2280 form factor

Steps.Text_raw: With the midframe removed, the M.2 SSD is now accessible Remove a torx screw holding the M.2 holding the SSD to the motherboard Pull the SSD straight back Do not pull the SSD upward or risk damaging the M.2 socket The M.2 socket is compatible with most SATA III, PCIe ACHI, and PCIe NVMe in the M.2 2280 form factor

Subject: M.2 SSD

Title: Cleaning Inside Your Inspiron

Lines.Text: first attach your anti static wrist band to both yourself and the chassis of the computer . you may need to move your wrist band around to different areas to make it easier while dismantling and that's fine . just remember to have it connected at all times when handling the parts .
now we can begin taking the pc apart . to start simply remove the two case screws on the back .

Steps.Text_raw: First attach your Anti Static wrist band to both yourself and the chassis of the computer. You may need to move your wrist band around to different areas to make it easier while dismantling and that's fine. Just remember to have it connected at all times when handling the parts. Now we can begin taking the PC apart. To start simply remove the two case screws on the back.

Lines.Text: next we are going to lay the tower on it's right side ( side where motherboard is attached ) and slide the cover off .

Steps.Text_raw: Next we are going to lay the tower on it's right side (side where motherboard is attached) and slide the cover off.

Lines.Text: before moving on , make sure that nothing is plugged into the ports on the front of the pc . if there is anything plugged into them , please remove them now .

Steps.Text_raw: Before moving on, make sure that nothing is plugged into the ports on the front of the PC. If there is anything plugged into them, please remove them now.

Lines.Text: ++while putting light++ downward pressure on the side of the face cover ( red ) , apply gentle upwards pressure to the three clips ( orange ) .

Steps.Text_raw: ++While putting LIGHT++ downward pressure on the side of the face cover (red), apply gentle upwards pressure to the three clips (Orange).

Lines.Text: once the three clips are free from the internal case you will see the face panel swing down . simply lift the front of the pc up while it is laying on it's side , and the face cover will unhook from the other side .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the three clips are free from the internal case you will see the face panel swing down. Simply lift the front of the PC up while it is laying on it's side, and the face cover will unhook from the other side.

Lines.Text: next remove the three screws holding the hdd and optical drive in place . it is very important that you '''do not''' remove the drives yet as they are still plugged into the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Next remove the three screws holding the HDD and Optical Drive in place. It is very important that you '''DO NOT''' remove the drives yet as they are still plugged into the motherboard.

Lines.Text: next we need to unplug the cables from the back of the optical drive and hdd . do not grab the wires to pull . get a firm grip on the hard plastic plugin and gently rock the cord side to side until it comes free .
keep in mind there are two cords for your optical drive , and two cords for your hdd to make a total of four that need to be unplugged .

Steps.Text_raw: Next we need to unplug the cables from the back of the Optical Drive and HDD. Do not grab the wires to pull. Get a firm grip on the hard plastic plugin and gently rock the cord side to side until it comes free. Keep in mind there are two cords for your Optical Drive, and two cords for your HDD to make a total of four that need to be unplugged.

Lines.Text: now that the screws are removed and cables unplugged . very carefully lift the drives out . they slide directly up and out . make sure to set your drives with the hdd facing up like you see in red box . to reassemble your drives carefully line them up in the space with the orange box outlined .
then carefully set them inside the pc . it lines up perfect and comes close to the sata cords on the motherboard . make sure nothing is getting pressed down underneath when reassembling .

Steps.Text_raw: Now that the screws are removed and cables unplugged. Very carefully lift the drives out. They slide directly up and out. Make sure to set your drives with the HDD facing up like you see in Red Box. To reassemble your drives carefully line them up in the space with the orange box outlined. Then carefully set them inside the PC. It lines up perfect and comes close to the SATA cords on the motherboard. Make sure nothing is getting pressed down underneath when reassembling.

Lines.Text: before you use the canned air or air compressor on the inside , make sure to remove those pesky sata cords as they tend to grab and hold onto pet hair and other dust chunks . be careful when reassembling as the ports are numbered . 0 is the first sata port your motherboard will load so make sure your hdd is plugged into 0.

your optical drives plugs into the number 1 which is right next to your 0 port . 1 will be loaded second so make sure your optical drive is connected to that . otherwise when you turn your pc on , it will not load your operating system , which is the interface you see when using your pc .

Steps.Text_raw: Before you use the canned air or Air Compressor on the inside, make sure to remove those pesky SATA Cords as they tend to grab and hold onto pet hair and other dust chunks. Be careful when reassembling as the ports are numbered. 0 is the first SATA port your motherboard will load so make sure your HDD is plugged into 0. Your Optical Drives plugs into the number 1 which is right next to your 0 port. 1 will be loaded second so make sure your Optical Drive is connected to that. Otherwise when you turn your PC on, it will not load your Operating System, which is the Interface you see when using your PC.

Lines.Text: ++'''note : ''' ''we are not removing the heat sink in this guide as that requires cleaning of its own and reapplying thermal paste . it is very important you check the second photo in this step to make sure you are taking the correct screws out . ''++
remove the four screws around the edge of the fan and make sure to unplug the power wire to the fan ( photo 3 ) . once unplugged and screws removed , you may gently take out the heat sink fan .

Steps.Text_raw: ++'''Note:''' ''We are NOT removing the heat sink in this guide as that requires cleaning of its own and reapplying thermal paste. It is VERY important you check the second photo in this step to make sure you are taking the correct screws out.''++ Remove the four screws around the edge of the fan and make sure to unplug the power wire to the fan (Photo #3). Once unplugged and screws removed, you may gently take out the heat sink fan.

Lines.Text: with everything out of our way we can begin cleaning . you may clean in any order you wish . when cleaning the heat sink fan ( red ) do not let the fan spin . when cleaning the heat sink grill ( orange ) you may find it best to use cotton . start in the center and pull to the outer edge to clean .

make sure you spray underneath your motherboard . there is a small gap between your chassis and motherboard shown in the blue marker . dust , pet hair , and other debris like to hide under there . to finish up make sure to spray the back peripheral ports and the front ports . also spray down system fans making sure not to let them spin !

Steps.Text_raw: With everything out of our way we can begin cleaning. You may clean in any order you wish. When cleaning the Heat Sink Fan (Red) DO NOT let the fan spin. When cleaning the Heat Sink Grill (Orange) you may find it best to use cotton. Start in the center and pull to the outer edge to clean. Make sure you spray underneath your motherboard. There is a small gap between your chassis and motherboard shown in the blue marker. Dust, pet hair, and other debris like to hide under there. To finish up make sure to spray the back peripheral ports and the front ports. Also spray down system fans making sure not to let them spin!

Lines.Text: if you would like to clean the front case , simply take a damp cloth and wipe it down . make sure it fully dries before reassembly otherwise you risk water damage to the pc .

if cleaning the optical and hdd drive be very careful not to drop or slam the hdd as you will damage your data and os . meaning when you reassemble the pc , you will not have an operating system to come back to . also be careful not to spray to close to parts as condensed air has high moisture content at close range .

Steps.Text_raw: If you would like to clean the Front Case, simply take a damp cloth and wipe it down. Make sure it fully dries before reassembly otherwise you risk water damage to the PC. If cleaning the Optical and HDD Drive be very careful not to drop or slam the HDD as you will damage your DATA and OS. Meaning when you reassemble the PC, you will not have an Operating System to come back to. Also be careful not to spray to close to parts as condensed air has high moisture content at close range.

Title: Asus Zen AiO Pro Z240IC Screen Replacement

Lines.Text: use the plastic opening tool to pry off the black plastic strip at the bottom of the screen by wiggling the tool between the strip and the screen .
the strip is held in place with adhesive . you may hear a crackling sound as the strip is peeled off .
run the opening tool slowly along the base of the screen , peeling the black strip back , until the opposite end of the screen is reached .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the plastic opening tool to pry off the black plastic strip at the bottom of the screen by wiggling the tool between the strip and the screen. The strip is held in place with adhesive. You may hear a crackling sound as the strip is peeled off. Run the opening tool slowly along the base of the screen, peeling the black strip back, until the opposite end of the screen is reached.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the seven ( 7 ) 4.8 mm screws from the base of the screen .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the seven (7) 4.8 mm screws from the base of the screen.

Lines.Text: place the computer on its back , facing up .
wedge the plastic opening tool in between the screen and the bezel of the aluminum computer casing .
move the tool along the entire edge of the screen with an up-and-down prying motion to loosen the screen from the casing . do not lift the entire screen away from the computer yet .
the screen is held in place by plastic tabs . these will create a popping sound when loosened .
the screen assembly will flex as it is pried off . do not bend the screen too far or the glass screen could shatter .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the computer on its back, facing up. Wedge the plastic opening tool in between the screen and the bezel of the aluminum computer casing. Move the tool along the entire edge of the screen with an up-and-down prying motion to loosen the screen from the casing. Do not lift the entire screen away from the computer yet. The screen is held in place by plastic tabs. These will create a popping sound when loosened. The screen assembly will flex as it is pried off. Do not bend the screen too far or the glass screen could shatter.

Lines.Text: lift the screen from the bottom edge by about 6 inches . prop it open with one hand .
look inside the computer and locate five ( 5 ) cables that connect the embedded components of the screen ( camera , microphone , etc . ) to the rest of the computer .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the screen from the bottom edge by about 6 inches. Prop it open with one hand. Look inside the computer and locate five (5) cables that connect the embedded components of the screen (camera, microphone, etc.) to the rest of the computer.

Lines.Text: remove the two ( 2 ) cables that are connected to the computer by white , rectangular terminal blocks by pulling straight out on the plug .
the cables and wires in these steps are delicate ; do not tug on the individual wires that make up each cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two (2) cables that are connected to the computer by white, rectangular terminal blocks by pulling straight out on the plug. The cables and wires in these steps are delicate; do not tug on the individual wires that make up each cable.

Lines.Text: use a finger to lift the plastic locking flaps that hold the remaining three ( 3 ) ribbon cables in place .
remove the cables from their terminals by slipping them away from their connectors .
the black line on the ribbon cables mark the connecting region . when reinstalling , insert the cable up to the this line so the locking flap covers it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a finger to lift the plastic locking flaps that hold the remaining three (3) ribbon cables in place. Remove the cables from their terminals by slipping them away from their connectors. The black line on the ribbon cables mark the connecting region. When reinstalling, insert the cable up to the this line so the locking flap covers it.

Subject: Screen

remove power and sata cables from on top of the drive .

remove three 1.2 cm phillips 1 screws that connect the fan with the main body .

Lines.Text: remove the six ( 6 ) ribbon cables by lifting up on the plastic locking tabs and then slipping the cables out of their sockets .

one ribbon cable is hidden beneath black tape .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six (6) ribbon cables by lifting up on the plastic locking tabs and then slipping the cables out of their sockets. Remove the other two (2) cables by pulling straight out on the white connectors. One ribbon cable is hidden beneath black tape. The motherboard is ESD sensitive. Limit your contact with the green circuit board surface and electrical components. When handling the board, hold it by the edges. The black lines on the ribbon cables mark the connecting region. When reinstalling, insert the cables up to this line so the locking flap covers it.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove nine ( 9 ) 3.2 mm screws from the motherboard .
two of the screws near the middle of the board are hidden beneath padding .
use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the one ( 1 ) 4.8 mm screw directly below the copper heat sink channel .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove nine (9) 3.2 mm screws from the motherboard. Two of the screws near the middle of the board are hidden beneath padding. Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the one (1) 4.8 mm screw directly below the copper heat sink channel.

Lines.Text: lift the motherboard just enough to dismount it from the plastic pegs that hold it in place .
rotate the motherboard towards yourself while supporting the heat sink by pivoting on its bottom edge .

Lines.Text: disconnect pc from power source and any other devices .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect PC from power source and any other devices.

Lines.Text: turn over computer and remove the rubber feet .
remove the three 8 mm phillips screws with a phillips 0 screwdriver .
use a pry tool and lift up on the lid .

Steps.Text_raw: Turn over computer and remove the rubber feet. Remove the three 8mm Philips screws with a Philips #0 screwdriver. Use a pry tool and lift up on the lid.

Lines.Text: remove the two cables connecting the motherboard to the front i/o panel .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two cables connecting the motherboard to the front I/O panel.

Lines.Text: from the back i/o panel , pry open the cloth covering .

Steps.Text_raw: From the back I/O panel, pry open the cloth covering.

Lines.Text: remove the 2 black phillips screws on the outside of the pc , to the left of the fan .
there is one on the top and one on the bottom .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the 2 black philips screws on the outside of the PC, to the left of the fan. There is one on the top and one on the bottom.

Lines.Text: put your thumb on the penny-sized hole , and slide the panel upwards .
remove the panel to reveal the stock blue ram .

Steps.Text_raw: Put your thumb on the penny-sized hole, and slide the panel upwards. Remove the panel to reveal the stock blue RAM.

Lines.Text: push both of the white tabs away from the ram stick to free the ram .

Steps.Text_raw: Push both of the white tabs away from the RAM stick to free the RAM.

Lines.Text: you can now easily pull the ram out of the socket , and replace up to two new ones !

Steps.Text_raw: You can now easily pull the RAM out of the socket, and replace up to two new ones!

Title: Asus Zen AiO Pro Z240IC Heat Sink Replacement

Lines.Text: use the plastic opening tool to pry off the black plastic strip at the bottom of the screen by wiggling the tool between the strip and the screen .
the strip is held in place with adhesive . you may hear a crackling sound as the strip is peeled off .
run the opening tool slowly along the base of the screen , peeling the black strip back , until the opposite end of the screen is reached .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the plastic opening tool to pry off the black plastic strip at the bottom of the screen by wiggling the tool between the strip and the screen. The strip is held in place with adhesive. You may hear a crackling sound as the strip is peeled off. Run the opening tool slowly along the base of the screen, peeling the black strip back, until the opposite end of the screen is reached.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the seven ( 7 ) 4.8 mm screws from the base of the screen .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the seven (7) 4.8 mm screws from the base of the screen.

Lines.Text: place the computer on its back , facing up .
wedge the plastic opening tool in between the screen and the bezel of the aluminum computer casing .
move the tool along the entire edge of the screen with an up-and-down prying motion to loosen the screen from the casing . do not lift the entire screen away from the computer yet .
the screen is held in place by plastic tabs . these will create a popping sound when loosened .
the screen assembly will flex as it is pried off . do not bend the screen too far or the glass screen could shatter .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the computer on its back, facing up. Wedge the plastic opening tool in between the screen and the bezel of the aluminum computer casing. Move the tool along the entire edge of the screen with an up-and-down prying motion to loosen the screen from the casing. Do not lift the entire screen away from the computer yet. The screen is held in place by plastic tabs. These will create a popping sound when loosened. The screen assembly will flex as it is pried off. Do not bend the screen too far or the glass screen could shatter.

Lines.Text: lift the screen from the bottom edge by about 6 inches . prop it open with one hand .
look inside the computer and locate five ( 5 ) cables that connect the embedded components of the screen ( camera , microphone , etc . ) to the rest of the computer .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the screen from the bottom edge by about 6 inches. Prop it open with one hand. Look inside the computer and locate five (5) cables that connect the embedded components of the screen (camera, microphone, etc.) to the rest of the computer.

Lines.Text: remove the two ( 2 ) cables that are connected to the computer by white , rectangular terminal blocks by pulling straight out on the plug .
the cables and wires in these steps are delicate ; do not tug on the individual wires that make up each cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two (2) cables that are connected to the computer by white, rectangular terminal blocks by pulling straight out on the plug. The cables and wires in these steps are delicate; do not tug on the individual wires that make up each cable.

Lines.Text: use a finger to lift the plastic locking flaps that hold the remaining three ( 3 ) ribbon cables in place .
remove the cables from their terminals by slipping them away from their connectors .
the black line on the ribbon cables mark the connecting region . when reinstalling , insert the cable up to the this line so the locking flap covers it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a finger to lift the plastic locking flaps that hold the remaining three (3) ribbon cables in place. Remove the cables from their terminals by slipping them away from their connectors. The black line on the ribbon cables mark the connecting region. When reinstalling, insert the cable up to the this line so the locking flap covers it.

Lines.Text: locate the wlan card in the upper left hand corner of the computer .
use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the 3.2 mm screw on the top of the wlan card .

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the WLAN card  in the upper left hand corner of the computer. Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the 3.2 mm screw on the top of the WLAN card.

Lines.Text: pull out the wlan card from its socket .
remove the two antennae wires from the wlan card by pulling up on the coaxial connectors .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull out the WLAN card from its socket. Remove the two antennae wires from the WLAN card by pulling up on the coaxial connectors.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 0 screwdriver to remove the three ( 3 ) 4.8 mm screws from the fan unit .
remove the cable connecting the fan to the motherboard by pulling the cable out of its socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #0 screwdriver to remove the three (3) 4.8 mm screws from the fan unit. Remove the cable connecting the fan to the motherboard by pulling the cable out of its socket.

Lines.Text: remove the fan by peeling off the black electrical tape holding it against the heat sink vents .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the fan by peeling off the black electrical tape holding it against the heat sink vents.

Lines.Text: remove the six ( 6 ) ribbon cables by lifting up on the plastic locking tabs and then slipping the cables out of their sockets .
remove the other two ( 2 ) cables by pulling straight out on the white connectors .
one ribbon cable is hidden beneath black tape .
the motherboard is esd sensitive . limit your contact with the green circuit board surface and electrical components . when handling the board , hold it by the edges .
the black lines on the ribbon cables mark the connecting region . when reinstalling , insert the cables up to this line so the locking flap covers it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six (6) ribbon cables by lifting up on the plastic locking tabs and then slipping the cables out of their sockets. Remove the other two (2) cables by pulling straight out on the white connectors. One ribbon cable is hidden beneath black tape. The motherboard is ESD sensitive. Limit your contact with the green circuit board surface and electrical components. When handling the board, hold it by the edges. The black lines on the ribbon cables mark the connecting region. When reinstalling, insert the cables up to this line so the locking flap covers it.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove nine ( 9 ) 3.2 mm screws from the motherboard .
two of the screws near the middle of the board are hidden beneath padding .
use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the one ( 1 ) 4.8 mm screw directly below the copper heat sink channel .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove nine (9) 3.2 mm screws from the motherboard. Two of the screws near the middle of the board are hidden beneath padding. Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the one (1) 4.8 mm screw directly below the copper heat sink channel.

Lines.Text: lift the motherboard just enough to dismount it from the plastic pegs that hold it in place .
rotate the motherboard towards yourself while supporting the heat sink by pivoting on its bottom edge .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the motherboard just enough to dismount it from the plastic pegs that hold it in place. Rotate the motherboard towards yourself while supporting the heat sink by pivoting on its bottom edge.

Lines.Text: remove the sata cable on the opposite side of the motherboard by pulling directly up from the board .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the SATA cable on the opposite side of the motherboard by pulling directly up from the board.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to loosen the four ( 4 ) large silver screws evenly in the order of the numbers engraved next to each screw .
use a phillips 0 to loosen the other four ( 4 ) 2.4 mm screws evenly in the order engraved on the copper next to each screw .
repeat the last two bullets until all the larger silver screws make a clicking sound and the 2 mm screws are removed .
the silver screws cannot be completely removed .
peel away the black tape between the ram shield and the heat sink .
when reattaching the heat sink to the motherboard , make sure to tighten the screws a little bit at a time , in the same order as before , until they are all snug .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to loosen the four (4) large silver screws evenly in the order of the numbers engraved next to each screw. Use a Phillips # 0 to loosen the other four (4) 2.4 mm screws evenly in the order engraved on the copper next to each screw. Repeat the last two bullets until all the larger silver screws make a clicking sound and the 2mm screws are removed. The silver screws cannot be completely removed. Peel away the black tape between the RAM shield and the heat sink. When reattaching the heat sink to the motherboard, make sure to tighten the screws a little bit at a time, in the same order as before, until they are all snug.

Lines.Text: remove the heat sink by lifting up .
during reassembly , make sure to use a fresh application of thermal paste . refer to the following guide :

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the heat sink by lifting up. During reassembly, make sure to use a fresh application of thermal paste. Refer to the following guide: https://www.ifixit.com/Guide/How+to+Apply+Thermal+Paste/744

Lines.Text: use the plastic opening tool to pry off the black plastic strip at the bottom of the screen by wiggling the tool between the strip and the screen .
the strip is held in place with adhesive . you may hear a crackling sound as the strip is peeled off .
run the opening tool slowly along the base of the screen , peeling the black strip back , until the opposite end of the screen is reached .

Steps.Text_raw: Use the plastic opening tool to pry off the black plastic strip at the bottom of the screen by wiggling the tool between the strip and the screen. The strip is held in place with adhesive. You may hear a crackling sound as the strip is peeled off. Run the opening tool slowly along the base of the screen, peeling the black strip back, until the opposite end of the screen is reached.

Lines.Text: use a phillips 1 screwdriver to remove the seven ( 7 ) 4.8 mm screws from the base of the screen .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a Phillips #1 screwdriver to remove the seven (7) 4.8 mm screws from the base of the screen.

Lines.Text: place the computer on its back , facing up .
wedge the plastic opening tool in between the screen and the bezel of the aluminum computer casing .
move the tool along the entire edge of the screen with an up-and-down prying motion to loosen the screen from the casing . do not lift the entire screen away from the computer yet .
the screen is held in place by plastic tabs . these will create a popping sound when loosened .
the screen assembly will flex as it is pried off . do not bend the screen too far or the glass screen could shatter .

Steps.Text_raw: Place the computer on its back, facing up. Wedge the plastic opening tool in between the screen and the bezel of the aluminum computer casing. Move the tool along the entire edge of the screen with an up-and-down prying motion to loosen the screen from the casing. Do not lift the entire screen away from the computer yet. The screen is held in place by plastic tabs. These will create a popping sound when loosened. The screen assembly will flex as it is pried off. Do not bend the screen too far or the glass screen could shatter.

Lines.Text: lift the screen from the bottom edge by about 6 inches . prop it open with one hand .
look inside the computer and locate five ( 5 ) cables that connect the embedded components of the screen ( camera , microphone , etc . ) to the rest of the computer .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the screen from the bottom edge by about 6 inches. Prop it open with one hand. Look inside the computer and locate five (5) cables that connect the embedded components of the screen (camera, microphone, etc.) to the rest of the computer.

Lines.Text: remove the two ( 2 ) cables that are connected to the computer by white , rectangular terminal blocks by pulling straight out on the plug .
the cables and wires in these steps are delicate ; do not tug on the individual wires that make up each cable .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two (2) cables that are connected to the computer by white, rectangular terminal blocks by pulling straight out on the plug. The cables and wires in these steps are delicate; do not tug on the individual wires that make up each cable.

Lines.Text: use a finger to lift the plastic locking flaps that hold the remaining three ( 3 ) ribbon cables in place .
remove the cables from their terminals by slipping them away from their connectors .
the black line on the ribbon cables mark the connecting region . when reinstalling , insert the cable up to the this line so the locking flap covers it .

Steps.Text_raw: Use a finger to lift the plastic locking flaps that hold the remaining three (3) ribbon cables in place. Remove the cables from their terminals by slipping them away from their connectors. The black line on the ribbon cables mark the connecting region. When reinstalling, insert the cable up to the this line so the locking flap covers it.

Lines.Text: disconnect the ribbon cable from the side that has mb labeled on it by lifting up on the black locking flap and pulling the cable out of its terminal .
the black line on the ribbon cable marks the connecting region . when reinstalling , insert the cable up to this line so the locking flap covers it .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the ribbon cable from the side that has "MB" labeled on it by lifting up on the black locking flap and pulling the cable out of its terminal. The black line on the ribbon cable marks the connecting region. When reinstalling, insert the cable up to this line so the locking flap covers it.

Lines.Text: remove the four ( 4 ) 3.2 mm screws with a phillips 1 screwdriver .
one screw is hidden under the ribbon cable .
lift the board gently upwards to remove it from the base of the computer .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four (4) 3.2 mm screws with a Phillips #1 screwdriver. One screw is hidden under the ribbon cable. Lift the board gently upwards to remove it from the base of the computer.

Title: HP 310-1037 Cooler Replacement

Lines.Text: hp310-1037 touchsmart pc with a dead hard drive . the hard drive is located behind the stand cover .
lay the pc flat on the front to gain access to the stand cover
remove the single screw that holds the stand cover to the chassis with a flat tip screwdriver

Steps.Text_raw: HP310-1037 Touchsmart PC with a dead hard drive. The hard drive is located behind the stand cover. Lay the PC flat on the front to gain access to the stand cover Remove the single screw that holds the stand cover to the chassis with a flat tip screwdriver

Lines.Text: remove the stand cover
the hard drive caddy is held in place with 1 phillips screw
use a 0 phillips screwdriver to remove that screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the stand cover The hard drive caddy is held in place with 1 Phillips screw Use a #0 Phillips screwdriver to remove that screw

Lines.Text: lift the handle on the hard drive caddy
and pull it to the backside . this will remove the hard drive caddy from the computer .
to remove the hard drive from the caddy , turn it over . there are four phillips scres that hold the hard drive in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the handle on the hard drive caddy and pull it to the backside. This will remove the hard drive caddy from the computer. To remove the hard drive from the caddy, turn it over. There are four Phillips scres that hold the hard drive in place.

Lines.Text: once the four screws are removed , slide the hard drive out of the caddy .
here is the failed drive . it is a hitachi hds721010 cla332. failure with this drive is all to common .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the four screws are removed, slide the hard drive out of the caddy. Here is the failed drive. It is a Hitachi HDS721010CLA332. Failure with this drive is all to common.

Lines.Text: remove the four torx/flathead screws securing the stand .
lift the bottom part of the stand upwards , and it will come off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four Torx/Flathead screws securing the stand. Lift the bottom part of the stand upwards, and it will come off.

Lines.Text: remove the four torx/flathead screws securing the back cover .
also unscrew the two captive phillips screws securing the disc drive , as these two screws also secure the back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four Torx/Flathead screws securing the back cover. Also unscrew the two captive Philips screws securing the disc drive, as these two screws also secure the back cover.

Lines.Text: remove the seven silver torx/flathead screws securing the metal shield .
remove the single black torx/flathead screw securing the metal shield .
remove the cables strung through the shield .
pull up on the shield to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the seven silver Torx/Flathead screws securing the metal shield. Remove the single black Torx/Flathead screw securing the metal shield. Remove the cables strung through the shield. Pull up on the shield to remove it.

Lines.Text: remove the two torx/flathead screws securing the fan .
pull up on the fan connector to remove it .
lift the fan to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Torx/Flathead screws securing the fan. Pull up on the fan connector to remove it. Lift the fan to remove it.

Lines.Text: remove the six phillips screws securing the heatsink assembly to the motherboard .
carefully lift the heatsink . if it won't come off , twist it as you pull it off . if it still won't come off , pull harder .

unfortunately , if you have to resort to pulling harder , the processor will likely come off with the heatsink . if this happens , use an adjustable heat gun set to 200 c to soften the thermal paste , first .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six Philips screws securing the heatsink assembly to the motherboard. Carefully lift the heatsink. If it won't come off, twist it as you pull it off. If it still won't come off, pull harder. Unfortunately, if you have to resort to pulling harder, the processor will likely come off with the heatsink. If this happens, use an adjustable heat gun set to ~200C to soften the thermal paste, first.

Subject: Cooler

Title: HP 310-1037 Motherboard Replacement

Lines.Text: hp310-1037 touchsmart pc with a dead hard drive . the hard drive is located behind the stand cover .
lay the pc flat on the front to gain access to the stand cover
remove the single screw that holds the stand cover to the chassis with a flat tip screwdriver

Steps.Text_raw: HP310-1037 Touchsmart PC with a dead hard drive. The hard drive is located behind the stand cover. Lay the PC flat on the front to gain access to the stand cover Remove the single screw that holds the stand cover to the chassis with a flat tip screwdriver

Lines.Text: remove the stand cover
the hard drive caddy is held in place with 1 phillips screw
use a 0 phillips screwdriver to remove that screw

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the stand cover The hard drive caddy is held in place with 1 Phillips screw Use a #0 Phillips screwdriver to remove that screw

Lines.Text: lift the handle on the hard drive caddy
and pull it to the backside . this will remove the hard drive caddy from the computer .
to remove the hard drive from the caddy , turn it over . there are four phillips scres that hold the hard drive in place .

Steps.Text_raw: Lift the handle on the hard drive caddy and pull it to the backside. This will remove the hard drive caddy from the computer. To remove the hard drive from the caddy, turn it over. There are four Phillips scres that hold the hard drive in place.

Lines.Text: once the four screws are removed , slide the hard drive out of the caddy .
here is the failed drive . it is a hitachi hds721010 cla332. failure with this drive is all to common .

Steps.Text_raw: Once the four screws are removed, slide the hard drive out of the caddy. Here is the failed drive. It is a Hitachi HDS721010CLA332. Failure with this drive is all to common.

Lines.Text: remove the four torx/flathead screws securing the stand .
lift the bottom part of the stand upwards , and it will come off .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four Torx/Flathead screws securing the stand. Lift the bottom part of the stand upwards, and it will come off.

Lines.Text: remove the four torx/flathead screws securing the back cover .
also unscrew the two captive phillips screws securing the disc drive , as these two screws also secure the back cover .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the four Torx/Flathead screws securing the back cover. Also unscrew the two captive Philips screws securing the disc drive, as these two screws also secure the back cover.

Lines.Text: remove the seven silver torx/flathead screws securing the metal shield .
remove the single black torx/flathead screw securing the metal shield .
remove the cables strung through the shield .
pull up on the shield to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the seven silver Torx/Flathead screws securing the metal shield. Remove the single black Torx/Flathead screw securing the metal shield. Remove the cables strung through the shield. Pull up on the shield to remove it.

Lines.Text: remove the two torx/flathead screws securing the fan .
pull up on the fan connector to remove it .
lift the fan to remove it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Torx/Flathead screws securing the fan. Pull up on the fan connector to remove it. Lift the fan to remove it.

Lines.Text: remove the six phillips screws securing the heatsink assembly to the motherboard .
carefully lift the heatsink . if it won't come off , twist it as you pull it off . if it still won't come off , pull harder .

unfortunately , if you have to resort to pulling harder , the processor will likely come off with the heatsink . if this happens , use an adjustable heat gun set to 200 c to soften the thermal paste , first .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the six Philips screws securing the heatsink assembly to the motherboard. Carefully lift the heatsink. If it won't come off, twist it as you pull it off. If it still won't come off, pull harder. Unfortunately, if you have to resort to pulling harder, the processor will likely come off with the heatsink. If this happens, use an adjustable heat gun set to ~200C to soften the thermal paste, first.

Lines.Text: remove all attached connectors from the motherboard .
remove the four remaining screws securing the motherboard . you're done !

Steps.Text_raw: Remove all attached connectors from the motherboard. Remove the four remaining screws securing the motherboard. You're done!

Subject: Motherboard

Title: Dell Optiplex GX620 Fan Replacement

Lines.Text: power down your pc and remove the power cord from the back .

Steps.Text_raw: Power down your PC and remove the power cord from the back.

Lines.Text: press and hold the power button for about 10 seconds , then release .
this helps drain any remaining power stored in the capacitors , so that you can safely work on the internal components .

Steps.Text_raw: Press and hold the power button for about 10 seconds, then release. This helps drain any remaining power stored in the capacitors, so that you can safely work on the internal components.

Lines.Text: with the computer standing upright , firmly pull on the tab at the back of the computer .
when the side panel pops free , gently pull the panel away from the computer .
if you have trouble freeing the side panel from the case , you may need to pull the tab a bit harder .

Steps.Text_raw: With the computer standing upright, firmly pull on the tab at the back of the computer. When the side panel pops free, gently pull the panel away from the computer. If you have trouble freeing the side panel from the case, you may need to pull the tab a bit harder.

Lines.Text: unplug your hard drives power and data cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug your hard drives power and data cables.

Lines.Text: unplug the power and data cables .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the power and data cables.

Lines.Text: unplug the fan .

Steps.Text_raw: Unplug the fan.

Lines.Text: remove the two phillips 2 screws .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two Phillips #2 screws.

Lines.Text: pull the heat sink up .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the heat sink up.

Lines.Text: pull the two tabs and pull it out .
this needs a lot of force to take it off .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the two tabs and pull it out. This needs a lot of force to take it off.

Lines.Text: to take the fan out you have to pull the two tabs and pull the fan out .

Steps.Text_raw: To take the fan out you have to pull the two tabs and pull the fan out.

Lines.Text: turn off the computer , unplug all cables , and let it cool down . lay the computer flat on its screen .
make sure that the work surface is flat and has nothing sharp on it .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the two screws on the bottom of the computer, one on each side.

Lines.Text: locate the slot on the right side of the computer next to the screw hole . use a plastic opening tool or spudger to pry off the rear cover . ( dont be afraid to use a little force . )

Steps.Text_raw: Locate the slot on the right side of the computer next to the screw hole. Use a plastic opening tool or spudger to pry off the rear cover. (Don’t be afraid to use a little force.)

Lines.Text: once it has been separated , lift to remove .

Title: ASUS Portable AiO PT2001 RAM Replacement

Lines.Text: remove the grey scuff guard at the bottom of the pc by pressing down on it , and pulling it away .
lift the hinge and remove the grey rubber tabs on either side of the pcs model information .
remove the two 7.62 mm phillips 1 screws beneath the rubber tabs under the hinge and the four 7.62 mm phillips 1 screws where the scuff guard was removed .
remove the two 4.74 mm phillips 1 screws under the hinge ( near the hinge joints ) and a 4.74 mm phillips 1 screw under the handle .

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the grey scuff guard at the bottom of the PC by pressing down on it, and pulling it away. Lift the hinge and remove the grey rubber tabs on either side of the PC’s model information. Remove the two 7.62mm Phillips #1 screws beneath the rubber tabs under the hinge and the four 7.62mm Phillips #1 screws where the scuff guard was removed. Remove the two 4.74mm Phillips #1 screws under the hinge (near the hinge joints) and a 4.74mm Phillips #1 screw under the handle.

Lines.Text: use 1-2 plastic opening tools or nylon spudgers to firmly pry open the back panel .
we recommend that you start prying the panel where the scuff guard was removed .
prying the back panel will cause loud popping noises . this is just the sound of the clips that hold the back panel to the pc popping off .
using excess force while prying can break the clips that hold the back panel and can damage the ports on the side of the pc .

Steps.Text_raw: Use 1-2 plastic opening tools or nylon spudgers to firmly pry open the back panel. We recommend that you start prying the panel where the scuff guard was removed. Prying the back panel will cause loud popping noises. This is just the sound of the clips that hold the back panel to the PC popping off. Using excess force while prying can break the clips that hold the back panel and can damage the ports on the side of the PC.

Lines.Text: disconnect the three cables connecting the back panel ports to the motherboard .
flip up the locking latch holding the two ribbon cables with a plastic opening tool and pull the cables out .
gently wiggle the third connector out of its socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the three cables connecting the back panel ports to the motherboard. Flip up the locking latch holding the two ribbon cables with a plastic opening tool and pull the cables out. Gently wiggle the third connector out of its socket.

Lines.Text: peel off the tape attaching the metal enclosure to the heat sink .
lift the metal enclosure off of the motherboard .

Steps.Text_raw: Peel off the tape attaching the metal enclosure to the heat sink. Lift the metal enclosure off of the motherboard.

Lines.Text: pull the jaws of the white plastic frame apart . this will pop the front of the ram up .
gently lift the front edge of the ram .
pull the ram out and up .

Steps.Text_raw: Pull the jaws of the white plastic frame apart. This will pop the front of the RAM up. Gently lift the front edge of the RAM. Pull the RAM out and up.

Subject: RAM

Steps.Text_raw: Remove the grey scuff guard at the bottom of the PC by pressing down on it, and pulling it away. Lift the hinge and remove the grey rubber tabs on either side of the PC’s model information. Remove the two 7.62mm Phillips #1 screws beneath the rubber tabs under the hinge and the four 7.62mm Phillips #1 screws where the scuff guard was removed. Remove the two 4.74mm Phillips #1 screws under the hinge (near the hinge joints) and a 4.74mm Phillips #1 screw under the handle.

Lines.Text: use 1-2 plastic opening tools or nylon spudgers to firmly pry open the back panel .
we recommend that you start prying the panel where the scuff guard was removed .
prying the back panel will cause loud popping noises . this is just the sound of the clips that hold the back panel to the pc popping off .
using excess force while prying can break the clips that hold the back panel and can damage the ports on the side of the pc .

Steps.Text_raw: Use 1-2 plastic opening tools or nylon spudgers to firmly pry open the back panel. We recommend that you start prying the panel where the scuff guard was removed. Prying the back panel will cause loud popping noises. This is just the sound of the clips that hold the back panel to the PC popping off. Using excess force while prying can break the clips that hold the back panel and can damage the ports on the side of the PC.

Lines.Text: disconnect the three cables connecting the back panel ports to the motherboard .
flip up the locking latch holding the two ribbon cables with a plastic opening tool and pull the cables out .
gently wiggle the third connector out of its socket .

Steps.Text_raw: Disconnect the three cables connecting the back panel ports to the motherboard. Flip up the locking latch holding the two ribbon cables with a plastic opening tool and pull the cables out. Gently wiggle the third connector out of its socket.

Lines.Text: the two in-house speakers are located near the sides of the device with the motherboard in between .
remove the two 2.35 mm phillips 1 screws from each speaker .

Steps.Text_raw: The two in-house speakers are located near the sides of the device with the motherboard in between. Remove the two 2.35 mm Phillips #1 screws from each speaker.

Lines.Text: the two speakers are attached to each other with a cord that is threaded along the side of the casing . gently pull the wire out
the cord is secured under two pieces of tape with multiple other wires . make sure that you only remove the wire connecting the speakers .
keep in mind that when replacing the wires , you will need to secure the tape again . accordingly , be careful not to tear the tape when peeling it .

Steps.Text_raw: The two speakers are attached to each other with a cord that is threaded along the side of the casing. Gently pull the wire out The cord is secured under two pieces of tape with multiple other wires. Make sure that you only remove the wire connecting the speakers. Keep in mind that when replacing the wires, you will need to secure the tape again. Accordingly, be careful not to tear the tape when peeling it.

Lines.Text: pull the cord attached to the speaker out of the motherboard
